SUMMARY: - reinforcement learning is one of three basic machine learning paradigms

- reinforcement learning agent AI interacts with its environment in discrete time steps
- The goal of a reinforcement learning agent is to learn a policy that maximizes the expected cumulative reward
- The agent chooses an action from a set of available actions and sends it to the environment
- in order to act near optimally, an agent must reason about the long-term consequences of its actions
- regret is the difference in performance of an agent that acts optimally to one that doesn't
- regret occurs when an agent acts to maximize future income rather than its immediate reward
- reinforcement learning can be used to deal with large environments
- it is particularly well-suited to problems that include a long-term versus short-term reward trade-off
- it has been applied to robot control and other problems
- two elements make reinforcement learning powerful: the use of samples and function approximation
- reinforcement learning requires clever exploration mechanisms

- exploitation trade-off has been studied in the multi-armed bandit problem and for finite state space MDPs

- where is a parameter controlling the amount of exploration vs
- exploitation

- Other methods use heuristics to control exploration and exploitation in a similar way
- The agent's action selection is modeled as a map called policy
- The policy map gives the probability of taking action when in a state
- There are also deterministic policies for the agent's actions
- the agent can choose actions that lead to higher cumulative rewards
- value function estimates "how good" it is to be in a given state

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Supervised.TITLE: Supervised learning - Wikipedia
SUMMARY: - supervised learning is the task of learning a function that maps an input to an output based on example pairs
- It infers a function from labeled training data consisting of a set of training examples
- In supervised learning, each example is a pair of input-output pairs
- supervised learning is a form of machine learning
- To solve a problem of supervised learning, a user needs to gather a training set of examples
- The user then needs to decide the type of data to be used
- The engineer must then decide the structure of the learned function and an algorithm
- there is no single learning algorithm that works best on all supervised learning problems
- a wide range of supervised learning algorithms are available
- each has its own strengths and weaknesses
-  No single algorithm works best for all supervisedlearning problems
- there is a tradeoff between bias and variance in supervised learning
- The bias of a classifier is related to the variance of the learning algorithm
- A learning algorithm with high variance is biased when trained on different training data sets
- Many supervised learning methods can adjust this tradeoff
- The amount of training data available relative to the complexity of the "true" function is an issue
- If the true function is simple, a "flexible" learning algorithm with high bias and low variance can learn it from a small amount of data
- The same is true for a complex regression function
- a third issue is the dimensionality of the input space
- if the input feature vectors have large dimensions, learning the function can be difficult
- manually removing irrelevant features from the input data can improve the accuracy of the classifier
- many algorithms for feature selection seek to identify the relevant features and discard irrelevant ones
- a fourth issue is the degree of noise in the desired output values of the supervisory target variables
- learning algorithm should not attempt to find a function that matches the training examples
- Attempting to fit the data too carefully can lead to overfitting
- Deterministic noise can corrupt your training data
- there are several approaches to alleviate noise in the output values of a supervised learning algorithm
- Early stopping to prevent overfitting and removing noisy training examples prior to training can reduce generalization error with statistical significance
- There are several algorithms that identify noisy trainingexamplesto reduce noise
- some algorithms are easier to apply than others when dealing with heterogeneous data
- Some algorithms require that the input features be numerical and scaled to similar ranges
- Other factors to consider include the presence of interactions and non-linearities
- decision trees and neural networks can help with these issues
- Tuning the performance of a learning algorithm can be very time-consuming
- It is often better to spend more time collecting additional training data and features
- Engineers can compare multiple learning algorithms to determine which works best for a new application
- Cross validation is a way to test different learning algorithms

- TD learning is an unsupervised technique in which the learning agent learns to predict the expected value of a variable at the end of a sequence of states
- RL allows the learned state-values to guide actions to change the environment
- supervised learning is a general approach to predicting the weather on Saturday
- Sutton (1988) shows how to train a network to predict the weather in the week leading up to it
- Sutton says the actual weather conditions on each day of the week are relevant to predicting Saturday's weather
- unsupervised learning tries to use intermediate information to learn to predict the weather
- The method is different from the pairwise method of learning on observation-outcome pairs
- Sutton says the unsupervised approach is based on the idea that predictions are not confirmed all at once but bit by bit
- we will focus on the method of Temporal-Difference (TD) learning for unsupervised learning in prediction problems
- In connectionist applications, the predicting function is realized in a neural network
- The principles we will explore can be implemented by methods other than neural networks
- The general supervised learning paradigm can be summarized in a familiar formula
- Back propagation is the same computation that underlies back propagation
- we use weights in the network to calculate the gradient of the learning rate constant in a sequence of steps
- where m is the number of steps in the sequence and z is the error of predictions on adjacent time steps
- TD learning can be used to represent the error in terms of the sum of changes in predictions on previous steps
-    in TD learning, the error is called z - V
- sequence update rule is a weight update rule for a single time step
- The rule can be derived from the sequence update formula for weight changes
- The weight rule is the sum of differences and differences for the error in the formula
-   the weight rule has a formula for the weight change
- we need two successive predictions to form the error term
- learning is occuring retroactively for already visited states
- the update rule updates all previous predictions to make each closer to prediction V for the current state
- Temporal-Difference learning is the name of this type of learning
- this is a generalization of the TD(1) method
- it produces weight changes that supervised methods cannot produce
- it allows weight updates to occur incrementally over a sequence
- Sutton (1988) developed the generalization to TD(λ) in 1988
- We have added a constant, λ,  which exponentially discounts past gradients
-   the gradient of a prediction occurring n steps in the past is weighted by
- The method is similar to a supervised method using observation-outcome pairs as a training set

https://plato.stanford.edu/entries/schop.TITLE: Schopenhauerâs Aesthetics (Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy)
SUMMARY: - this entry focuses on Schopenhauer’s aesthetic theory
- the theory is found predominantly in Book 3 of the World as Will and Representation
- the entry offers a brief background on the philosopher's metaphysics
- it also addresses his methodology in aesthetics and his hierarchy of the arts
- Arthur Schopenhauer’s philosophy gained “ascendency in Europe” in the 1870s
- Schönberg says many philosophers, writers, composers and artists were influenced by his thought
- Schoenberg:   his work was published in relative obscurity until 1853
- Schopenhauer’s doctrine of the world includes a world of representation and the will qua thing in itself
- The two are two sides of the same coin, he says
- The world is a combination of the Kantian and the human will in itself, he argues
- Schopenhauer’s metaphysics and philosophy of nature led him to the doctrine of pessimism
- He held that sentient beings suffer as virtual slaves to their will to life
- The philosopher's view of nature was a proto-Darwinian theory of nature
- Schopenhauer sees a salutary role for the intellect in human life
- He identifies three main ways in which the intellect breaks free from the will to life
- These include aesthetic experience and artistic production, compassionate attitudes and actions, and ascetic resignation from embodied existence
- Schopenhauer praises Kant for deepening the subjective turn in philosophical aesthetics
- He says that the phenomenon of beauty can only be illuminated through a careful scrutiny of its effects on the subject
- He argues that Kant's aesthetic method is too indirect due to the transcendental argument
- Schopenhauer does not believe that the aesthetician should start from aesthetic judgment but from immediate aesthetic experience
- He argues that there is non-conceptual knowledge that we gain through aesthetic experiences of nature and art
- Schopenhauer says this knowledge is not conceptual, but rather intuitive
- Schopenhauer argues that Kant's aesthetic judgment is at one remove from true aesthetic experience
- He argues that the aesthetic judgment constitutes the wrong focus for aesthetic theorizing
- Schopenh Bauer argues that we try to translate intuitive knowledge into conceptual knowledge by abstraction
- fundamentally,  the gap between aesthetic experience and aesthetic judgments is a difficulty for aesthetic theories
- Schopenhauer is frank about the methodological limits of aesthetic theorizing
- He argues that aesthetic theories cannot capture the richness of immediate, first-personal aesthetic experience
- aesthetic experience comes in two main varieties for Schopenhauer: the beautiful and the sublime
- the beautiful experience can be had through perception of nature and art
- Schopenhauer's aesthetic theory includes the "picturesque" but not the beautiful

https://networkencyclopedia.com/terminal.TITLE: 403 Forbidden
SUMMARY: - a terminal is any device that terminates a communication channel
- A terminal is a device that acts as a front end for a mainframe or terminal server
- The term terminal is used in computer networking
- Terminal is an input/output device in computer terminology
- teletypes were essentially electric typewriters used to type commands and data for a mainframe
- teletypes were the earliest terminals used to communicate with other computers
-   Teletypes were first used in the late 1950s and early 1960s in the U.S
- a terminal that supports only text output is sometimes called an ASCII terminal
- terminal is responsible only for processing and queuing input from the keyboard.Terminals have little or no inherent data-processing power and rely on the back-end system to do the processing
- terminal protocols originated in the mainframe environment
- VT-100 terminal originated by Digital Equipment Corporation was a popular ASCII-text terminal standard
- IBM's 3270 terminal protocol is still widely used in mainframe environments
- other terminal standards include ANSI, VT52, and VT220
- terminals can be either local or remote
- popularity of terminals declined in the late 1980s and early 1990s with the advent of distributed client/server environments
- Data processing is shared between the client and the back-end server in a client/ server environment
- a terminal emulator is a stripped-down PC with no operating system that runs as a terminal
- A terminal server is a back-end server that delivers the user desktop environment to the terminals
- In the late 1990s, PC-based terminal emulators and terminal servers became popular

- what understands Chinese?

https://thesephist.com/posts/resonant/.TITLE: Resonant | thesephist.com
SUMMARY: - The article discusses the concept of resonance in physics.
- It explains that resonance occurs when an object vibrates at its natural frequency.
- The article goes on to say that if two objects with different resonant frequencies are next to each other, they will dampen each other's vibrations.
- However, if two objects with the same resonant frequency are next to each other, they will reinforce each other's vibrations.
-If you sing into the sound chamber of a piano at a specific pitch and then stop, you'll hear the few strings that were tuned to your note continue to vibrate.
-The author has had deep relationships with people who they felt naturally resonated with and they believe this is because they shared some resonant frequency.
-When people share a resonant frequency, they are able to communicate effectively and understand each other deeply.
- The author reflects on times when they have been pulled towards another person by their frequencies.
- They note that this has occurred with both strangers and people the author knows.
- The author has been lucky enough to resonate with some of these people, leaving lasting echoes in their memory.
-The text discusses the idea that people can resonant with other people on a deep level.
-It argues that often when somebody seems to deeply resonate with one part of us, they end up dampening other parts of us.
-This can be confusing and painful to experience.
- The text discusses the difficulty of finding people who resonate with us.
- The author suggests that we pay attention to our own strings and listen for vibrations in order to find someone who is deeply resonant with us.

https://thesephist.com/posts/focus/.TITLE: How to find focus | thesephist.com
SUMMARY: - The individual has been easy to focus lately and attributes this to having fewer things on their to-do list.
- The individual also has a stronger sense of values, which has helped clear their schedule.
- The individual is thinking about what might have changed to cause this shift.
- The individual has changed their thinking and now believes that the few things they are spending their time on are right for them.
- Last year, if somebody had come up and said that they were doing it all wrong, they would have been easily swayed but today they feel much more confident.
- Because they are confident in what they are doing, it is easy for them to say no to things that would take away time from those pursuits.
- The author suggests that confidence is earned, not found.
- To earn confidence, we need to explore our options and try things out.
- Only that kind of conviction, coming from true belief and not just blunt willpower, can give you the certainty you need to be focused on the few right things.
- The author suspects that this is the reason many students who take gap years or gap semesters return with more confidence and perspective.
- The author is discussing focus, and how it can be attained.
- According to the author, focus is not simply about saying "no" to more things.
- Instead, focus requires studying all the options until you can say with conviction which one is right for you.
- This means that attaining focus actually requires becoming less focused for a little while, in order to explore your options and develop conviction around what is important.
- The text discusses the idea that we are either in a divergent or convergent phase at any given moment.
- Divergent phases are focused on broadening inputs and exploring new paths, while convergent periods are focused on narrowing down goals and becoming more focused.
- These cycles of divergence and convergence come from the heart, not circumstance.
- You can't force focus by making a decision when you aren't confident it's right - this will only lead to worry about missed opportunities.
- The text discusses focus and how to achieve it.
- It argues that the only way to achieve focus is to work on the right thing for you and to try your chances with the paths that might be wrong.
- Drifting can help you feel less lost or directionless.
- Try new things and explore different options.
- Follow your gut when you feel the time is right.

https://saveall.ai/blog/learning-is-reme.TITLE: Learning is Remembering
SUMMARY: - This is a strategy for learning quantum mechanics.
- When you encounter a concept you don't understand, read about it until you do. If you encounter another concept you don't understand while reading about the first one, look it up.
- Remember where you were so you can come back and pick up where you left off.
-The strategy will not work because it is too difficult to learn quantum mechanics.
-Intuitively, we know this won't work.
-Try it yourself to see what will happen.
- The text discusses why learning from Wikipedia does not work.
- It explains that this is because our working memory has a maximum capacity of 4, and when we encounter new information, it can become full very quickly.
- As a result, we are only able to understand new information if it requires combining less than 4 new pieces of information.
- Our working memory's capacity is limited but our long-term memorys capacity is effectively unlimited.
- To learn more than 4 new concepts we must move some of them into our long-term memory before learning the rest.
- It is impossible to increase your working memory's capacity. Given this, to get faster at learning you must get more efficient at moving things into your long-term memory.
- Memory therefore heavily influences our learning speed.
- In 2019 the UK school inspection body Ofsted went further than this and changed their definition of learning itself to an alteration in long-term memory.
- Some estimate that we forget 90% of what we learn within a month
- Because of this, many people think improving your memory is inefficient and only helpful for "lesser" forms of learning.
- Memory has a bad reputation because of this belief.
- The story discusses the importance of memory.
- It states that many people believe that memory is unimportant because they had bad experiences with rote memorization in school.
- However, the author argues that memory is actually very important, and Googling something is not as efficient as remembering it.
- The text discusses the issue of forgetting and how it can be addressed.
- It argues that forgetting is a major problem and new technologies can help alleviate it.
- The text urges the UK education sector to join in correcting memory's bad reputation.

http://www.paulgraham.com/control.html.TITLE: Founder Control
SUMMARY: - The text discusses how startup founders can retain control of the board after a series A round.
- It explains that in the past, it was rare for founders to keep control of the board, but this has changed in recent years.

https://openai.com/api/pricing/.TITLE: Pricing
SUMMARY: - Completions requests are billed based on the number of tokens sent in your prompt plus the number of tokens in the completion(s) returned by the API.
- The and parameters may also impact costs.
- In the simplest case, if your prompt contains 10 tokens and you request a single 90 token completion from the davinci engine, your request will use 100 tokens and will cost $0.006.
- There are two components to fine-tuning pricing: training and usage.
- When training a fine-tuned model, the total tokens used will be billed according to our training rates (50% of our base model rates).
- The number of training tokens depends on the number of tokens in your training dataset and your chosen number of training epochs.
- Once you fine-tune a model, you'll be billed only for the tokens you use.
- Classifications requests are billed based on the number of tokens in the inputs you provide.
- Internally, this endpoint makes calls to the search and completions endpoints, so its costs are a function of the costs of those endpoints.
- The actual cost per token is based upon which models you select to perform both the search and the completion.
- You may provide a file containing the examples to search over, or you can explicitly specify in your request.
- Providing a file makes search faster and more cost effective when the number of examples you'd like to search over is greater than .
- In this scenario, costs are largely based on the number of examples reranked (controlled by ) and the total length of those examples.
- If you pass in your request instead, costs are based on the total length of all those examples.
- The length of the passed into the model as well as the final classification label that is generated will also factor into costs.
-You are billed based on the total number of tokens in the documents you provide, plus the tokens in the query and the tokens needed to instruct the model on how to perform the operation.
-The API also uses a reference document to generate a response, adding 1 to the total document count.
